issues.title: CoRIM standard for TDX
issues.author: Xynnn007
issues.body:
Hi @nedmsmith . I am Ding from [Confidential Containers](https://github.com/confidential-containers) which aiming to provide cloud native way to leverage TEE ability for containerized workload. Now I am working on the reference value publishment and consumption of the components running inside TEE (like kernel, guest firmware, ..., e.g. `mr_td`, `rtmr`s for TDX, etc.).

Two aims from my side
- Use a standard format as carrier of reference values. CoRIM is from IETF RATS and I'd like to use it first.
- The format should be extensible for different platforms, aiming for SGX/TDX/SNP/CCA/...

I have read the slides about [CoRIM based attestation framework](https://github.com/CCC-Attestation/meetings/blob/main/materials/ShanweiCen_CORIM_based_Attestation_Framework.pdf) which follows the `measurement-values-map-extension` fields defined in this repo. This could help SGX to give reference values for fields like `MRENCLAVE`. 

My question is how to apply this standard on TDX and other platforms? Is there anything I ignored or do you have any plan?

Thanks a lot!

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body: There are examples in https://github.com/nedmsmith/draft-cds-rats-intel-corim-profile/tree/main/cddl/examples that show Reference Values in cbor diag format. MRENCLAVE is modeled as a digest type. The Intel profile uses a different name from `mrenclave`. Instead, it is `tee.mrtee` (see -83). The name change allows sgx and tdx to use consistent naming.

comments.author: Xynnn007
comments.body:
Thanks for your reply @nedmsmith 

There is a practical problem. If I want to give a reference value manifest for `tdx-module`, I found there is [an example](https://github.com/nedmsmith/draft-cds-rats-intel-corim-profile/blob/main/cddl/examples/irim-seam-crs.diag)

```
          / measurement-map / {
            / mval / 1 : / measurement-values-map / {
              / vendor / -70 : "Intel Corporation",
              / model / -71 : "TDX SEAM",
              / attributes / -82 : 60010([ 1, h'C0000000000000000000000000000000', h'FBFFFFFFFFFFFFFF0000000000000000']), / *** 16 bytes *** /
              / isvprodid / -85 : 1,
              / isvsvn / -73 : 60010([ /op.ge/ 2, 6 ]),
              / mrsigner / -84 : [
                / alg-id / 1, / sha256 /
                / digest / h'A314FC2DC663AE7A6B6BC6787594057396E6B3F569CD50FD5DDB4D1BBAFD2B6A'
              ]
            },
            / authorized-by / 2 : [
              / tagged-pkix-base64-key-type / 554("base64_key_X")
            ]
```
And also quote.body format for TDX defined in DCAP
```
typedef struct _sgx_report2_body_t {
    tee_tcb_svn_t       tee_tcb_svn;          ///<  0:  TEE_TCB_SVN Array
    tee_measurement_t   mr_seam;              ///< 16:  Measurement of the SEAM module
    tee_measurement_t   mrsigner_seam;        ///< 64:  Measurement of a 3rd party SEAM module’s signer (SHA384 hash). 
                                              ///       The value is 0’ed for Intel SEAM module
    tee_attributes_t    seam_attributes;      ///< 112: MBZ: TDX 1.0
    tee_attributes_t    td_attributes;        ///< 120: TD's attributes
    tee_attributes_t    xfam;                 ///< 128: TD's XFAM
    tee_measurement_t   mr_td;                ///< 136: Measurement of the initial contents of the TD
    tee_measurement_t   mr_config_id;         ///< 184: Software defined ID for non-owner-defined configuration on the guest TD. e.g., runtime or OS configuration
    tee_measurement_t   mr_owner;             ///< 232: Software defined ID for the guest TD's owner
    tee_measurement_t   mr_owner_config;      ///< 280: Software defined ID for owner-defined configuration of the guest TD, e.g., specific to the workload rather than the runtime or OS
    tee_measurement_t   rt_mr[4];             ///< 328: Array of 4(TDX1: NUM_RTMRS is 4) runtime extendable measurement registers
    tee_report_data_t   report_data;          ///< 520: Additional report data
}sgx_report2_body_t;
```

So the implied mapping here is
- `mval.attributes` -> `quote.body.seam_attributes`
- `mval.mrsigner` -> `quote.body.mrsigner_seam`
- `mval.isvsvn` -> `quote.body.tee_tcb_svn`

Right?

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body: I believe that is a correct mapping. The thing to note is the profile relies on `environment-map` to disambiguate the object to which measurements apply. The DCAP usage encodes or implies the object in the measurement name. For example "mrsigner_seam" implies the seam object has the mrsigner measurement.

comments.author: Xynnn007
comments.body: Thanks very much. Do you have any plan inside Intel to publish reference values of TDX stack using CoRIM?

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body:
> Thanks very much. Do you have any plan inside Intel to publish reference values of TDX stack using CoRIM?

Yes. That's typically coordinated with product releases.

issues.title: Prefer mkey over redefining measurement values types?
issues.author: deeglaze
issues.body:
Given that we've restored multiplicity to measurements, it seems prudent to avoid re-specifying types of measurements for measured fields and instead use mkey numbers to represent the field, no?

Thinking from the perspective of tooling, it would be much simpler to give insights about reference values if folks stick to the standard types, and we can just have a mapping of class-id + mkey => colloquial measured field name, and visualization of particular values would not need any further enlightenment.

I'm wondering if we can try to avoid new profiles for every kind of attestation technology when they're not expressing fundamentally new concepts. The expression language you have here is something else.

Example:

```
$$measurement-values-map-extension //= (
     &(tee.pceid: -80) => $tee-pceid-type
   )
   $tee-pceid-type /= tstr
```
could be

> tee.pceid from TDQUOTE is transformed to
```
[/ mkey: / 0: 80, / mval: / 1: {/ name: / 11: tee.pceid}]
```

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body:
Yes, that would be a way to reduce dependence on the mvm extensions, however, that might only work for evidence as reference values (for at least several measurements) uses non-exact match semantics, so we might still need the extension points. There is also the matter of timing profiles with product releases.

A possible way forward is to work on a second profile that models some alternatives that make better use of base types.

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body: OK to close?

issues.title: Fix broken Expression CDDL
issues.author: yogeshbdeshpande
issues.body:
The Reference Values CDDL as it stands today is broken.


The primary reason been, for all expressions Intel Profile use Code Point #6.60010

And then the Operator has ambiguous ranges, meaning: 
 
BUG 1:
 
numeric-operator = gt / ge / lt / le with gt = 1
 
AND AT THE SAME TIME
 
mask-expression = [ mask-operator,  With mask-eq = 1

issues.title: Uniform approach for date time and epoch markers
issues.author: nedmsmith
issues.body:
There are primitives for time, date (tdate), and epoch markers that have overlapping semantics. It might make sense to combine them into a more comprehensive approach where a simple timestamp can be considered a simplified epoch marker where secure time / synchronized clocks are assumed (out of scope).

The epoch markers expression type can treat grace seconds as optional. By populating epoch-id with a timestamp value, the current simple use case for timestamps can be accommodated. 

Only one CBOR expression type 60030 is needed to handle the various forms for expressing epochs.

comments.author: yogeshbdeshpande
comments.body: Makes sense, i think, it will make the whole thing lot less complex (infact very simple)

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body:
The general idea is to allow grace period to be optional:
```
epoch-expression = [ 
    epoch-operators,
    grace-period: epoch-seconds-type,
    ? epoch-id: $tagged-epoch-id
]
```
becomes:
```
epoch-expression = [ 
    epoch-operators,
    non-empty<{
        ? grace-period: epoch-seconds-type
        ? epoch-id: $tagged-epoch-id
   }>
]
```
If grace-period is populated but not epoch-id, then current time is the defailt epoch-id.
If epoch-id is populated but not grace-period, then the epoch-id is used with a default clock drift to compute roughly equivalent times.
If both are specified then the epoch-id can be time or tdate (with CBOR tag) and grace-period is in ~time (seconds + or -).
If a more elaborate epoch marker is invented it just needs to be behind a CBOR tag.

Ideally, the draft-ietf-rats-epoch-markers doesn't define cddl too rigidly that this approach is considered compliant.

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body:
There is an issue in the epoch-markers repo that suggests that cbor-epoch-id isn't needed (https://github.com/ietf-rats/draft-birkholz-rats-epoch-marker/issues/36). If eliminated, time, tdate, and etime are elevated to epoch-id definitions:
```
$tagged-epoch-id /= tdate
$tagged-epoch-id /= time
$tagged-epoch-id /= etime
```
The epoch markers draft doesn't define operators per se for each epoch-id form. Instead, the CBOR tag implies semantics for its use. For example, given the following expression:
```
tagged-exp-epochm-ge = #6.60032([ op.ge, epoch-marker ])
$tagged-epoch-id /= #6.26991( epoch-grace-time)
```
The epoch `time` signifies a meridian epoch and grace-period can be either +/- seconds from the meridian. Hence, the expression operator op.ge/op.le isn't needed.

All of the epoch-ids can be defined in such a way that there is no need for an expression abstraction.

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body: fixed by #45, #47, and #49

issues.title: TDX profile does not need Mask Expressions
issues.author: yogeshbdeshpande
issues.body:
Mask as defined in base [CoRIM specification](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-rats-corim/)

is always matched exactly.

There is no need for an expression into the Mask based types.

Examples include:
TEE-TCB-STATUS 
TEE-MISC-SELECT

There are all, masks which exactly need to appear in an identical fashion in Evidence and Reference Value and they are an Exact Match

The Intel Profile needs to be tidied up to use the mask type from Base Spec and remove Mask Expressions altogether!

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body:
One option is to continue using the negative code point (for example `&(tee.attributes: -82)` ) and define `$tee-attributes-type = tagged-masked-raw-value`.  This can still be matched to Evidence expressed as `bytes`. The  `value` and `mask` in `tagged-masked-raw-value` corresponds to the `value` and `mask` in `mask-expression`. The operator is not needed.

Another option is to use mkey with a value of `82` and use `&(raw-value: 4)` to specify the `value` and `mask` using `tagged-masked-raw-value` for Reference Values and `tagged-bytes` for Evidence.

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body: Fixed by #50

issues.title: Add PCK certificate extensions as claims
issues.author: deeglaze
issues.body:
Verifying a TDX quote means checking the signatures along the collateral of PCK certificate back to Intel. https://api.portal.trustedservices.intel.com/content/documentation.html

The PPID claim in particular is important for a CSP to claim locality of specific machines in particular data centers.
Is here an appropriate place to state how the PCK certificate should be translated into concise evidence / CoMID format for conditional endorsement triple purposes?

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body:
> The PPID claim in particular is important for a CSP to claim locality of specific machines in particular data centers.

In TCG circles locality refers to the way a Root of Trust for Measurement / DICE connects to a TPM / DPE. In terms of CSPs and data centers, does it refer to logical/geographic location?

comments.author: deeglaze
comments.body: I'm not using the TPM notion of locality. Let's say machine residence. I'd like to provide endorsements that a machine resides in a particular Google Cloud Zone. We don't go down to data center granularity for consumers, so it wouldn't be entirely geographic location. We do tend to ensure zones are housed in appropriate jurisdictions for regulatory compliance.

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body: There is some flexibility in the values that could be used as platform identifiers. If PPID isn't supported long term, would a replacement that has a similar lifespan as PPID be acceptable? What is the ideal lifespan?

comments.author: deeglaze
comments.body: The ideal lifespan of a platform identifier is the total length of ownership for the package so long as there's a way to irrevocably destroy owner secrets for after-market sales. I'm not sure what correspondence the current platform identifier claim has to the PCK PPID, but as long as we have something along those lines, we should be good.

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body: The `platform-instance-id` is probably the best identifier for this purpose. `Platform` refers to the components that must work together to have a fully formed TCB. Upon first boot the combination of components (CPU, memory, etc) are recognized and an identifer is created that represents this combination. It is also known by the acronym PIID. The PPID is available on legacy systems, as is PIID, but PIID is supported longer term. Owner secrets are removed whenever PIID is reset. Changes to the TCB can cause PIID to be reset. This is good for security, but it also assumes the platform change control anticipates which changes might result in a TCB change.

issues.title: Request CBOR tag for operators
issues.author: nedmsmith
issues.body:
The CBOR tags for operators: 60010, 60020, and 60021 have not been officiall allocated by IANA. 
These can be allocated from the vendors specific regeon.

comments.author: yogeshbdeshpande
comments.body: ok, understood it is for the legacy reasons!

comments.author: yogeshbdeshpande
comments.body: leave it just bytes for now and we are done with this!

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body:
> leave it just bytes for now and we are done with this!

It is an option to document use of `&(raw-value: 4)` with an `mkey` of `81` or `82` to support `miscselect` and `attributes` use cases. This approach would allow exact match in reference values based on `tagged-bytes`.

comments.author: yogeshbdeshpande
comments.body:
> > leave it just bytes for now and we are done with this!
> 
> It is an option to document use of `&(raw-value: 4)` with an `mkey` of `81` or `82` to support `miscselect` and `attributes` use cases. This approach would allow exact match in reference values based on `tagged-bytes`.

Yes, thats what I was thinking. but you might have some products with just `bytes`, already encoded in evidence.

So how that would be handled if we encode it as coRIM `raw-value` ??

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body:
> So how that would be handled if we encode it as coRIM `raw-value` ??

The verifier would have to recognize that `mkey=81` is the same as the code point `-81`. If evidence is encoded with code point -81 and reference is encoded with mkey=81 then treat this as an equivalent expression. 

If in the future evidence is expressed with mkey=81, then Verifiers that don't support the Intel profile can process this.

comments.author: yogeshbdeshpande
comments.body:
> > So how that would be handled if we encode it as coRIM `raw-value` ??
> 
> The verifier would have to recognize that `mkey=81` is the same as the code point `-81`. If evidence is encoded with code point -81 and reference is encoded with mkey=81 then treat this as an equivalent expression.
> 
> If in the future evidence is expressed with mkey=81, then Verifiers that don't support the Intel profile can process this.

ok, makes sense, do you want to change mask-type to CoRIM raw-value?

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body:
> ok, makes sense, do you want to change mask-type to CoRIM raw-value?

No, because `raw-value-type-choice` doesn't support `~tagged-bytes`.
`mask-type` could become `$mask-type-choice` and then do something like:
```
$mask-type-choice /= ~tagged-bytes
$mask-type-choice /= $raw-value-type-choice
```

comments.author: yogeshbdeshpande
comments.body:
> raw-value-type-choice

It does, see the latest CoRIM SPec:

`
$raw-value-type-choice /= tagged-bytes
$raw-value-type-choice /= tagged-masked-raw-value

`

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body: `~tagged-bytes` != `tagged-bytes`

comments.author: yogeshbdeshpande
comments.body:
> `mask-type-choice` and then do something like:

Sorry i did not realized you were referring to `~tagged-bytes`.
Yes, in that case, we can do what you suggested..

comments.author: yogeshbdeshpande
comments.body:
> > `mask-type-choice` and then do something like:
> 
> Sorry i did not realized you were referring to `~tagged-bytes`. Yes, in that case, we can do what you suggested..

However, is it necessary? WHy ~tagged-bytes

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body: I pushed an update.

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body:
> However, is it necessary? WHy ~tagged-bytes

Evidence formats can't change at this point. And tagged-bytes adds 2 bytes for no apparent added value.
Where is the CDDL `time` defined ? Can you refer to the spec?
Why this cannot be just 560(bytes), i mean `tagged-bytes`?
563 is an array that contains the value and mask. tagged-bytes only has one value - no mask.
yes, but attributes, can be either `tagged-bytes` or `tagged-mask` (which is 563), is that right assumption?

```suggestion
$masked-value-type /= tagged-masked-raw-value
$masked-value-type /= tagged-bytes
```
Suggest we do this to allow cases when there is no mask!
As in the new one Mask is mandatory!

It can be 
```
mask-type = bstr
$masked-value-type /= mask-type
$masked-value-type /= tagged-masked-raw-value
```
tagged-bytes could be added. But I can't remove `mask-type` at the moment.

> As in the new one Mask is mandatory!

Not sure what you mean by mandatory. `$xxx-type` type-choice variants are optional.

comments.author: yogeshbdeshpande
comments.body:
> please see a .nit

I merged it on your PR, ok, to submit from my side!
Why is this file in the ignore list?

It is a generated file. Just like the autogen files. When CI runs it will generate it on github so you don't need to upload it (I think). When this PR is approved. I'll run cddl-releases to populate a release with this file in it.
Ok. I see that it is not part of the commit anymore. LGTM.

```suggestion
If everything goes as planned, "intel-profile.cddl" and the various "autogen" CDDL files will be available for download from the following locations:
```

pulls.title: get corim imports

pulls.body: Makefile changes to import corim exports directly rather than indirectly through concise evidence

pulls.title: Add RFC9581 period

pulls.body: Added RFC9581 period to tcbdate

pulls.title: Add int range
pulls.author: nedmsmith
pulls.body: Incorporate `raw-int` and `int-range` for `tee-tcb-comp-svn`, `tee-isvsvn`, and `tcb-eval-num`.

comments.author: yogeshbdeshpande
comments.body:
@nedmsmith Have you scoped the impact on concise-evidence library, due to this change ?

Will it not break the same, as now the fundamental type has been modified?

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body:
> Will it not break the same, as now the fundamental type has been modified?

No. The additional type options are added via `/=`. Implementations that depend on prior typing still work.

pulls.title: Pceid as int
pulls.author: nedmsmith
pulls.body: adds examples for pceid using `mkey`=80, as `raw-int` and added uint as a possible type for -80 code point.

pulls.author: nedmsmith
pulls.body: Removed instance-id which was a precursor to platform-instance-id

pulls.title: Added 32-byte piid example
pulls.author: nedmsmith
pulls.body: Clarified explanitory text in markdown and updated mkey example to show variable length platform instance identifier.

pulls.body: Did an editing pass and incorporated profile definitions for content-format and media-types.
